# List of Dallas Cowboys seasons

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

For complete team history, see [History of the Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/History_of_the_Dallas_Cowboys "History of the Dallas Cowboys").

This article is a list of seasons completed by the [Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") [American
football](/wiki/American_football "American football")
[franchise](/wiki/Professional_sports_league_organization "Professional sports
league organization") of the [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") (NFL). The
list documents the season-by-season records of the Cowboys' franchise from
[1960](/wiki/1960_NFL_season "1960 NFL season") to present, including
postseason records, and league awards for individual players or head coaches.
The Cowboys franchise was founded in 1960 as an expansion team.[1] The team
has earned 31 postseason appearances, tied for second place with the
[Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers"), the
longest consecutive streak of winning seasons with 20, the second-most
appearances in the [NFC Championship
Game](/wiki/National_Football_Conference_Championship_Game "National Football
Conference Championship Game") (14, behind the [San Francisco
49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")' 15) and the second-
most [Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") appearances (8 with the
[Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") and
[Steelers](/wiki/Steelers "Steelers")). The Cowboys have played for 10 [NFL
Championships](/wiki/History_of_National_Football_League_Championship "History
of National Football League Championship") and have won 5, all five being
Super Bowls.[2]

The Cowboys won [Super Bowl VI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_VI "Super Bowl VI"),
[XII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XII "Super Bowl XII"), [XXVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXVII
"Super Bowl XXVII"), [XXVIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXVIII "Super Bowl XXVIII") and
[XXX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXX "Super Bowl XXX"). They also played in and lost
[Super Bowl V](/wiki/Super_Bowl_V "Super Bowl V"), [X](/wiki/Super_Bowl_X
"Super Bowl X"), and [XIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XIII "Super Bowl XIII").[2]

The franchise has experienced two major periods of continued success in their
history. The first period of success came from [1966](/wiki/1966_NFL_season
"1966 NFL season")–[1985](/wiki/1985_NFL_season "1985 NFL season") when the
Cowboys played in the postseason 18 times.[3] During this period, they played
in two NFL Championships and five Super Bowls, winning two of them, winning a
total of 20 playoff games.[3] The second period of success was between
[1991](/wiki/1991_NFL_season "1991 NFL season")–[1996](/wiki/1996_NFL_season
"1996 NFL season") when the Cowboys captured five straight [NFC East
Division](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East") titles and won three Super Bowls going
11–2 in the postseason.[3]

Outside of these 2 periods of success, The Cowboys have experienced long
periods failure in their history. The three most notable periods of failure
was from their [1960 inaugural season](/wiki/1960_NFL_season "1960 NFL
season") to [1965](/wiki/1965_NFL_season "1965 NFL season"), during which the
Cowboys did not have a single postseason appearance.[4] They did not win a
single game during their first season, compiling an 0–11–1 record that is
still the worst in franchise history.[4] Also, they did not have a single
winning record in this period.[4] Between [1986](/wiki/1986_NFL_season "1986
NFL season") and [1990](/wiki/1990_NFL_season "1990 NFL season") the Cowboys
had losing records in each season as veteran coach Landry retired and the team
was radically overhauled, with the low point being the NFL's second 15-loss
season (after [the 1980 Saints](/wiki/1980_New_Orleans_Saints_season "1980 New
Orleans Saints season")) in [1989](/wiki/1989_NFL_season "1989 NFL season").
After losing [a Divisional playoff Game](/wiki/1996%E2%80%9397_NFL_playoffs
"1996–97 NFL playoffs") in 1996, the Cowboys between
[1997](/wiki/1997_NFL_season "1997 NFL season") and
[2008](/wiki/2008_NFL_season "2008 NFL season") lost five consecutive playoff
games, one after a franchise-record 13–3 season in 2007, during which most
predicted the Cowboys would break this streak.[5] This streak finally came to
an end when the Cowboys finally beat their bitter rival, the [Philadelphia
Eagles](/wiki/2009_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2009 Philadelphia Eagles
season") 34–14 after an 11–5 season in 2009.[5] From 1996 to 2017, a period of
21 years, The Cowboys have only 3 post season wins, all taking place in the
wild card round. In comparison since 2011 the Texans have an equal number(3)
of postseason wins. The teams combined winning percentage since 1996 is under
500 percent

  6. **Jump up ^** The [1967 NFL season](/wiki/1967_NFL_season "1967 NFL season") marks the first season in the league's history where the league was divided into two conferences which were subdivided into two divisions. Up to 1967, the league was either divided into two divisions, two conferences, or neither.
  7. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1973 season](/wiki/1973_NFL_season "1973 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") finished the season with identical 10–4 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Dallas finished ahead of Washington in the NFC East based on better point differential in head-to-head games.
  8. **Jump up ^** For the [1978 season](/wiki/1978_NFL_season "1978 NFL season"), the NFL expanded from a 14-game season to a 16-game season.
  9. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1978 season](/wiki/1978_NFL_season "1978 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Los Angeles Rams](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Rams_\(1946%E2%80%9394\) "Los Angeles Rams \(1946–94\)") finished the season with identical 12–4 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Los Angeles was the top NFC seed over Dallas based on a better head-to-head record.
  10. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1979 season](/wiki/1979_NFL_season "1979 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") finished the season with identical 11–5 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Dallas finished ahead of Philadelphia in the NFC East based on a better conference record.
  11. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1980 season](/wiki/1980_NFL_season "1980 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") finished the season with identical 12–4 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Philadelphia finished ahead of Dallas in the NFC East based on better net points in division games.
  12. **Jump up ^** The [1982 NFL season](/wiki/1982_NFL_season "1982 NFL season") was shortened from 16 games per team to 9 games because of a players' strike. The NFL adopted a special 16-team playoff tournament; eight teams from each conference were seeded 1–8, and division standings were ignored.
  13. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1985 season](/wiki/1985_NFL_season "1985 NFL season"), the Cowboys, [Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins"), and the [Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") finished the season with identical 10–6 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Dallas finished ahead of New York and Washington based on a better head-to-head record.
  14. **Jump up ^** The [1987 NFL season](/wiki/1987_NFL_season "1987 NFL season") was shortened from 16 games per team to 15 games because of a players' strike. Games to be played during the third week of the season were canceled, and replacement players were used to play games from weeks 4 through 6.
  15. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1991 season](/wiki/1991_NFL_season "1991 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears") finished the season with identical 11–5 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Chicago was the first NFC Wild Card based on better conference record than Dallas.
  16. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1996 season](/wiki/1996_NFL_season "1996 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") finished the season with identical 10–6 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Dallas finished ahead of Philadelphia in the NFC East based on better record against common opponents.
  17. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1999 season](/wiki/1999_NFL_season "1999 NFL season"), the Cowboys, [Lions](/wiki/Detroit_Lions "Detroit Lions"), and the [Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers") finished the season with identical 8–8 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Dallas was the second NFC Wild Card based on a better record than Detroit against common opponents and a better conference record than Carolina.
  18. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [2009 season](/wiki/2009_NFL_season "2009 NFL season"), the Cowboys and the [Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") finished with identical 11–5 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Dallas finished ahead of Philadelphia in the NFC East based on better head-to-head record.
